text: Orange pour, larger head, lots of lace. Earthy aroma, grapefruit, citrus juices. Grapefruit up front, melon, earthy, grass, light mango, heavier malt presence than other treehouse Ive had. Medium body, finish is grapefruit juice.

Pours a hazy, amber-peach, with good-sized head. Aroma has elements of citrus and pine/spruce hops. Flavor is very citrusy, with goodly amount of pine-hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is soft. Bitter finish. Excellent beer.

Can. Pours a cloudy orange with medium frothy white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is earth, pine, grapefruit pith, melon, pineapple. Fluffy mouth feel, grapefruit, melon, earth, pine, dank, nice bitterness, dry finish, very good.

Pours a hazy pale orange with a semi dense white head. Nose: very balanced hoppy character, some flowers, light resin, light bisquit. Taste: very hoppy for a pale ale. Light malty side as well but still more crisp and piney than anything else. Highly drinkable - this is really really solid. Wish I had access to this on a regular basis. Lovely hoppy aftertaste too.

Pour a quite hazy orange, with a rather large fluffy white head. 
Aroma of pine, nice citrus, slight grass, slight tree bark and bread dough in the very back. 
Taste is slightly bitter, but has some slight sweetness to it as Well. 
Watery body, with a flat carbonation.

Can, huge thanks to Chris. Pours out that cloudy copper color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is of tangerine, floral hops, light tropical fruit, some caramel and light melon. Taste is solid, juicy and complex with a moderate nod to caramel malts. Hops are juicy citrus, floral, perfume, light pine and some tangerine. Really nice offering.

Can. Pours a cloudy orange beer with a nice white stable head on top. Aroma is citrussy, nice hoppy, grassy and some mango. Flavor is light bitter, piney and some grapefruit juice, but not much. A nice malty body that finishes light sweet. Aftertaste is bittersweet and medium long. Nice carbonation. Decent balance. Good stuff.
Hazy yellow, medium white head. Fresh floral and piney hop aroma. Medium-light body. Crisp and fairly complex for being light, pine and citrus hops with malt in the background, very drinkable.

Can. Pours a hazy, pale orange, fluffy white head. Aroma was awesome and bursting with hops, citrus, and pine. Flavor fell off for me from the nose. Lemon, soap, lots of bread, pine, heavily bitter, even some sweetness mixed in. I prefer the juicier hoppy offerings from them over this one. Lighter body, sticky texture, bubbly carbonation, bitter bite to finish.

750 mL growler . Originally reviewed 11/3/2014.

Pale orange. Small white head. Nice collar and surface wisping.

Aroma is light lemon and orange hop. Slight herbal character.

Tastes like amarillo hops. Has that lemony flavor and some floral notes. Cracker malt in the middle. Mild herbal flavor in the back.

Light body. Medium low carbonation.

Decent pale ale, but doesnt stand out as very exciting.

Growler... Pours clear and yellow with a small, wispy, white head. Good retention. The aroma is bright, spicy, a touch earthy and a little crackery. Light to medium-bodied with adequate carbonation. The flavor is bittersweet with rindy hops and tea biscuits. Lengthy, bitter finish. Growler shared by biggsbowler!
Thanks again for the shares biggsbowler. Another solid yet disappointing pale from Tree House, fruity and relatively tasty but just not nearly as aggressive as offerings from Tired Hands/HF/RR.

Growler shared by biggsbowler. Clear light yellow pour with a white head. Mild fruity hop aromas. Tasty with grapefruit and citrusy hop notes. Nice balance with a sturdy caramel malt backbone. Good body and mouthfeel. A very nice APA.
Growler from Luke - A cloudy, yellow pour. Floral, piney, citrus notes in the nose. Grapefruit, piney, and resin taste. Nice light malt build. Very easy drinking
Tasted from 750ml, flip top growler fill. Poured a cloudy golden color with an averaged sized off white head. Citrus, floral hops, pine, with some caramel in the tastes. Very tasty APA.

[5678-20130817] Bottle. Grassy aroma. Slightly hazy, pale orange body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Bitter grassy hops flavour. Medium body. Good base IPA. (7/3/8/4/15) 3.7
(@ Campground Brewdown 2013, Millmont, PA)

Poured from a growler Into a Tree House Brewing stemmed glass.

The color is orange with yellow highlights with a finger of white head that leaves just a slight touch of lacing on the glass.

The smell has green grass aroma that gives some hints of earthy hops. There is a definite pine aroma in the nose that has some slight sweet candy aroma tied to it.

The taste is piney and resiny and really has a hop bite. There are touches of grapefruit and some citrus notes. The earthy spruce-tree flavor comes back toward the end and nips at the sides of your cheeks with bitterness.

The feel of this beer is medium bodied but does leave at times needing to really concentrate to wrap your head around this beer. There is a smooth drinkable feel that does offset an aftertaste that gives even more bitterness but does not wreck your palate.

Pours clear gold with a thick white head...nice lacing and retention. Aroma has great floral and grassy notes...like slightly herbal hop candy. Flavor follows suit but not so candy like...more grassy and herbal with light malt backing. Mouthfeel is light and the finish is dry and grassy / herbal.

Poured from growler into tulip: Pours hazy golden with a foamy white head and good lacing. Aroma is awesome, strong tropical fruits, grapefruit, grass, hay, and a little resin. Taste is a tropical bouquet, papaya and passion fruit, grapefruit, and hay. So smooth, medium body, a little sweet, but well balanced with all of the hops. Not bitter at all, but has lots of hop flavor. This might be my favorite beer from Tree House.

Cloudy orange pour, two finger white fluffy head. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit and some floral. Taste is grapefruit, pine, citrus and floral. Very easy to drink smooth pale ale. One of the best. Must try if you can get to brewery.

Bottle, savoured on March 14 2014; eye: golden, lightly hazy, tiny ring of off-white head, no lacing; nose: resinous hops, pine, tropical fruits, orange; mouth: resinous hops, pine, tropical fruits, orange, dry finale in orange with presence of tropical fruits, good carbonation, quite bitter, lightly harsh texture; overall: quite fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille, savourée le 14 mars 2014; il : dorée, légèrement voilée, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, pin, fruits tropicaux, orange; bouche : houblon résineux, pin, fruits tropicaux, orange, finale sèche en orange avec présence de fruits tropicaux, corsée, bonne carbonatation, pas mal amère, texture légèrement rugueuse; en résumé : bien bon

> A masterpiece papaya smoothie, silky and denser APA
[ Growler ][ 750ml ][ Tree House ][ $7 fill + $5 glass ][ Globe ][ 5/29/14 ]
>> High Hill Farmstead like fill on the growler, no pop, consumed hours after filling from the brewery tap room, which could be renamed to "growler filling station" as that is all that Tree House is- same with Hill Farmstead. Pours a beautiful, full haze, deeper orange with thicker, rocky yellow foam. Nose is lightly sticky, butterscotch, vanilla, fruity papaya, funky and overripe melon, strawberry. Taste is mildly acidic, mildly sweet papaya smoothie, silky mouthfeel with an oats or rye chewiness/density. Silky and soft body. Extremely juicy and lightly bitter like grapefruit and papaya blended. Dry, but not chalky or papery. Hop forward but not bitter. Mild sugar remains to give it body and balance. Really a masterpiece.
>!< probably worth the 1 hour+ detour

Growler split with GT2. Cloudy orange pour. Fresh farm and hay/grass aroma with juicy papaya and sweet orange. Taste is pineapple juice, grapefruit peel, grapefruit juice. Palate is really juicy and soft, low bitterness, small sugar remains. Awesome!

750ml swing top growler from the brewery. Pours an orange amber color with a white head and some lacing. Aroma is hoppy, floral, some grass, some grapefruit. Medium on the palate with soft, creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, bread, cereal, pine and grass hops, flowers, with a bittersweet floral finish. Definitely some pine and grapefruit in here, but flowers is the dominant hop note for me. Very nice.

Growler acheté directement à la brasserie au coût de 20.00$. Arôme: Odeur dorange et de de pamplemousse avec une pointe de fruits tropicaux. Apparence: La couleur est orangée légèrement voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle le verre. Saveur: Goût de pamplemousse avec une pointe dorange et de citron. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement houblonné. (Rating #5528)

Growler: Poured a nice golden/orangey color ale with a nice white foamy head. Aroma of tropical fruit with some very nice and fresh grapefruit notes. Taste is a wonderful mix of grapefruit notes with some light tropical notes. Nice presence of citrus notes with some very limited amount of bitterness. Body is about average with good carbonation. Quite a treat and glad I got a chance to try some of this.

Growler at Ottawa crews March tasting courtesy of Ian. Pale yellow with an off white head. Slightly musty citrus hoppiness with lemon and orange at the forefront, balanced caramel maltiness, somewhat sweet. Moderate body and carbonation, more bitter citrus on the palate and finish. Enjoyable and easy to drink.
hazy blonde with thin layer of head. smell of flora citrus notes, lemon peel and malt. Flavor of grapefruit juice, malt, biscuit. really solid

A hazed blonde ale with a thin white head. In aroma, a beautiful complex mix of citrusy and catty hops, biscuit malt, perfumy notes, very nice. In mouth, smooth fruity biscuit malt with floral, catty hops, citrus pulp, very balanced, quite nice. Growler from Ian Guenard.

My Bottom Line:
Grapefruit juice, flower petals, orange zest and pine needles whirl about this Pale Ales dry and quenching mouthfeel, building up to a tantalizing tasting youd which would never stop.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam settles atop the misty golden.
-The resinous hop bitterness is swift, not too sticky. This, and the lean nature of the body, increases drinkability greatly.
-The hop character is so bright and juicy it is hard to get tired of it.
-This already tastes like a Pale Ale which is as accomplished as Hill Farmsteads Edward.

On tap at the brewery and from a growler.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2016 750mL swingtop, bottled on 1/11/14, drunk 1/18/14Extremely tight carbonation produces a compact, creamy white head, atop a pale golden body, with a slight chill-haze to it. Head is well-retained. Pretty impressive appearance given the keg to swingtop production. Would certainly expect this from a bottle-conditioned beer. Appreciate the light haziness as well; its not filtered but has been given enough time to clear completely.Very strong aroma is all hoppiness...Mostly a citric IPA with navel oranges, white grapefruit and touches of lime. Perfectly attenuated malts give just a touch of honey on the end and balance the hop acids somewhat. With warming, I find tropical fruit notes; mango, pineapple and sweet lychee that add more depth to the hoppy presentation. No alcohol and most importantly no yeast stink, dirtiness or doughiness. AND no hop resin burn?? Literally not a touch of it. VERY impressive.Flavor follows from the nose. Tons of hoppiness, flavorful and moderately bitter, but the bitterness is spicy and citric, not resinous or alcoholic. Pale malts are soft and fully attenuated, giving the hops something to sink in to. Perfect balance and the mouthfeel, thanks to the tight carbonation, is creamy and supple.Really blown away by this stuff. Nothing flashy at all, just a wonderfully done pale ale. These guys have certainly made me a believer. The long wait-times to get their beer seem a little bit more understandable, having had this (and Julius, which is also stellar). Most impressed with the complete lack of resin burn (hop acid fatigue), yet without any sweet or thick maltiness. A study in balance.Rerate, canned 3/10/16, drunk 3/18/16.While this batch didnt live up to my memory of the previous batch I had, it was mostly that the carbonation was off, not so much any aspect of the aroma or flavor.  Just seemed a little loose and watery.  Granted this is not a big beer, but their growlers seem to have better carbonation than their cans, more often.  Really, really well-balanced beer and not flashy at all, as I remembered, with easygoing hoppiness and plenty of juiciness.  While this can certainly wasnt a 4.6, Im going to leave the score unchanged and chalk it up to the carbonation.  Will try again next back and see if this was just an anomaly.

750 ml flip top growler thanks to WillRunForBeer. Pours a very cloudy yellow-gold with a small foamy head that lingers nicely and leaves some oily webbing. Aroma of juicy pineapple, grapefruit, pine, and grapes. Tastes like tropical fruit juice with a strong pine presence. Strong bitter finish with a dry white wine aftertaste that seems to mix oddly with the pine/citrus/tropical fruit. Mouthfeel is pretty oily, nice sharp carbonation. Love everything about this except slight white wine in the finish. Thanks Brian.

Growler. Pours cloudy white gold with a clingy pure white head. Aroma is lemons, tropical fruit and grains. Sweet malt backbone with plenty of tangerine hop, grapefruit peel bitterness. Grapefruit and pine resin bitterness lingers in the somewhat oily finish.

tap @ brewery. tried side by side with julian, but liked this better. complex citrusy grapefruit, juicy clementine sweetness. taste has touch of pine and resin offered. dry. hops shine. nice balance. less of a malt focus than julius, and a bit lighter, which i preferred. nice to drink.

Growler thanks to jomobono! Pours a medium golden color with a finger of sticky foam. The nose is rustic straw, citrus a touch of lightly toasted malt and pine. The palate is focused clean and full of hop forward pleasant balance between the citrus fruit notes and grassy, straw and pine. Nice clean bitter finish. Really tasty and a good intro to this MA brewery !

Growler shared by yourefragile. Thanks Michael.

The beer is transparent and yellow with a soft white head. The aroma offers hops, tropical fruit, pine resin. Sweet and hoppy. Candied citrus and hops with a touch of warming alcohol. Lingering hop bitterness. Very tasty.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2014 Growler thanks to Brian - shared at tasting at my house. Pours cloudy gold with white head. Nose and taste of grapefruit, orange peel, caramel malt, light sticky resin and light spice. Medium body.

2013-08-17. Orange amber body with a small white head. 3+ Aroma is hoppy, sort of fruity, and notes of old pale malt. Flavour is mild, moderate hoppy bitterness throughout. Average bodied palate, modest carbonation. Just okay. At Campground Brewdown.
Growler at CGBD. Pours gold with a white head. Fruity hops, citrus and tropical, light grassy notes, and a nice medium dry bitter finish. Good stuff.

Sampled this at Campground Brewdown 2. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Soft citrus and hops on the nose. Medium-bodied, soft sweet caramel. Light wheat tones with some soft citrus coming through. Light alcohol and soft bitterness on the finish. Tasty.
Lemon, pine, tropical hop nose. Flavor is lemon & honey, berry, solid bitterness. Nice light malt.
Pours a cloudy and moderately dark orange with a white head. Pungent citrus and pine notes. Quite bitter. Like almost everything else Ive had from Tree House, its an absolute home run
Draft at Armsby abbey. Yellow orange pour. Orange citrus aroma, pine. Great flavor. Awesome pale ale

Draft at Armsby Abbey. Glowing golden orange body, medium white head, dense lacing. Digging the resinous pine and citrus rind here. Assertive bitterness that is supported by enough flavor. Medium bodied, appropriately carbonated. Nice biting finish.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2014 Small growler in a Tree House tulip.  Pours hazy, golden with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of citrusy and resinous hops and some pale and caramel and cereal malts.  Flavor the same, with a nice amount of hops and the typical Tree House malt character.  Average texture.  A pretty good IPA.
Edit: A really good IPA.  No Julius, but its good.

Pours really nicely from a growler into my tulip glass.  golden copper with nice one finger offwhite head.  Aroma is tons of resinous piney goodness with a citrusy fruity backbone.  Really promising off the aroma.  The taste is out of balance sadly.  This is way to bitter for me.  Going into such a low abv beer (this batch was 5.6% not 6.3%)  Soft carbonation with pine and fruity flavors just gets hammered by abrasive bitterness.  With a little refining I will really enjoy this one, but who knows maybe the harsh bitterness is intended.  Still an interesting beer from a fantastic local brewery,

Growler with a bunch of people at a pbw tasting. Pours clearish golden with small head/lace. Notes of cheese, light corn, pine, and citrus rind. A little dry and ashy at times but for the most part it was pine resin and juicy hopping. 2nd best I have had next to Julius.
growler from brewery, a very very bitter pale ale, very piney and resiny, meh, its way too bitter for my liking
